STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 3, 2024
Lindsey Lassanske
NEWAYGO/LAKE COUNTY DHHS
1018 E NEWELL ST,
WHITE CLOUD, MI, 49349-8795
RE: License#: CP620201323
Dear Lindsey Lassanske:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on August 21, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP620201323
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Lindsey Lassanske
Name of Agency: NEWAYGO/LAKE COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 1018 E NEWELL ST
WHITE CLOUD, MI 49349-8795
Agency Telephone #: 2316895500
Original Issuance Date: 08/01/1990
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 7/29/2024

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (a) Approval from the certifying agency
authorizing the placement of a child in the
home.
One of three borrowed bed files did not have documentation the borrowing
agency received approval from certifying agency prior to placing a child in a foster
home.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (c) The initial evaluation and current
reevaluation.

One of three borrowed bed files did not have documentation the borrowing
agency reviewed the initial evaluation and current reevaluation prior to placing a
child in a foster home.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following
incident reporting protocols:
• (b) Notification of the child's parents, the
responsible agency, and guardian ad
litem as applicable within 24 hours of
knowledge of the following:
• (i) Any injury of a foster child that
requires medical treatment.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation an incident
report was completed when a foster youth obtained an injury that required
medical treatment.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's name prior to placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (b) Child's date of birth.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's date of birth prior to placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (c) Available known information about the
child's health.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known health information.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (d) Any known history of abuse or neglect
of the child.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known abuse/neglect history.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (e) All known emotional and
psychological factors relating to the care
of the child.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known emotional and psychological factors.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (f) All known behaviors of the child.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known behaviors.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (g) Circumstances necessitating
placement or replacement of the child.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided circumstances necessitating placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (h) Any other known information to enable
the foster parent to provide a stable, safe,
and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including
information about siblings who do not
reside in the foster home as provided in
federal law.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided any known information to enable foster parent to provide a safe,
stable, and healthy environment for the foster child and the foster family including
any sibling information.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of six foster care files reviewed had a Updated Service Plan submitted
outside of the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023

CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans
• (1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
• (a) Dates, types, and places of agency
contacts and persons contacted.
One of six foster home files reviewed contained a service plan with a gap in
service dates and therefore did not have documentation of dates, types and
places of agency contacts and persons contacted.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of three independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to youth quarterly as
required.

FOM 722-06H Contact with parent or guardian when child is
placed out-of-home
When a child has a permanency goal of reunification,
the case manager must have face-to face contact with
legal parents and guardians as outlined in this section.
First Month after Initial Out-of-Home Placement
The case manager must have at least two face-to-face
contacts with the legal parent or guardian, with at least
one contact occurring at the parent or guardian's home
or living environment, during the first month following
initial out-of-home placement.
Subsequent Calendar Months
The case manager must have face-to-face contact with
the legal parent or guardian at least once per calendar
month. At least one contact each quarter must occur in
the parent’s residence.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the agency
made adequate attempts to contact and engage biological parent in case plan.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required tiem frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change
of placement or no later than three business days after
an unplanned change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,

stepdown from a residential or hospital setting, return
from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
Four of six foster care files reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023
8/31/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/22/2022
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS 1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
busiess days of the FTM.
Four of six foster care files reviewed and one of three independent living files
reviewed contained FTM's without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105 was not
uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023
8/31/2022, RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/22/2022
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
After the caseworker routes the service plan to the
supervisor for reviewe and approval, the supervisor
must approve all case service plans within 14 days of
the end of the report.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the
case service plan within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023
8/31/2022, RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/22/2022

FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement
agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Three of six foster care files reviewed and two of three independent living files
reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on the parent agency
treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023
8/31/2022, RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/22/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Annotate on signature line of PATP if mailed, emailed, refused, etc.
• If SOP is impacted for any reason, then upload corresponding documentation
for necessary verification of what is causing the impact on the SOP.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency interim inspection was completed on 9/8/23 and the CAP was
approved on 9/18/23. The agency was cited for 7 violations, 5 of which were
repeated this year. Of those 5, there was an improvement in individual incidents of
non-compliance within 3 of the violation areas (placement outlines, overdue
service plans and FTM's) and a slight increase in number of individual incidents in
the other 2 areas (PATP's. and 1105's) In 2022, 8 violations were established, 4 of
which were repeated this year. All of the repeated violations remain close to the
same number of individual incidents of non-compliances. The agency will need to
establish additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a
reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. The CA indicated the previous
year's CAP has had a positive impact on the agency's overall compliance. The CA
noted the CAP was developed in partnership with direct staff and supervisors to
ensure whole program buy in and successful implementation. The agency
regularly reviews data to determine trends and the need for further staff training.
The CA expressed confidence the agency will continue to see improvement over
the next review period.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors and coworkers are available to assist if
needed. Staff did not report any concerns but noted more support should be given
to new staff to assist with learning aspects of the job.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely and
there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Safety Alert #1: Licensed foster home was missing an operable smoke detector
between the master bedroom and the rest of the home.

Resolution: A new smoke detector was installed between the master bedroom and
the rest of the home and was verified by photographs the worker provided. A special
evaluation was also initiated, and a screenshot was provided for verification.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
___________8/21/2024_______________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
9/3/2024
_____________________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
